title: 2013 NCAA Division I FCS football season
text:
The 2013 NCAA Division I FCS football season, part of <a href="college%20football">college football</a> in the United States, was organized by the <a href="National%20Collegiate%20Athletic%20Association">National Collegiate Athletic Association</a> (NCAA) at the <a href="NCAA%20Division%20I">Division I</a> <a href="Football%20Championship%20Subdivision">Football Championship Subdivision</a> (FCS) level. The season began on August 29, 2013, and concluded with the <a href="2014%20NCAA%20Division%20I%20Football%20Championship%20Game">2014 NCAA Division I Football Championship Game</a> on January 4, 2014, at <a href="Toyota%20Stadium%20%28Texas%29">Toyota Stadium</a> in <a href="Frisco%2C%20Texas">Frisco, Texas</a>.
Notable changes.
For 2013, the FCS playoffs expanded for the first time since 2010. The <a href="Pioneer%20Football%20League">Pioneer Football League</a> champion now receives an automatic bid into the FCS playoffs, which increased to 24 teams.
Under a standard provision of NCAA rules, all FCS programs were allowed to play 12 regular-season games (not counting conference title games) in 2013, and also in 2014. In years when the period starting with the Thursday before <a href="Labor%20Day">Labor Day</a> and ending with the final Saturday in November contains 14 Saturdays, FCS programs may play 12 games instead of the regular 11. After 2014, the next season in which 12-game seasons are allowed will be 2019.
Conference changes and new programs.
Several teams changed conferences from the 2012 season, with all moves officially taking effect on July 1, 2013.
<a href="Albany%20Great%20Danes%20football">Albany</a> and <a href="Stony%20Brook%20Seawolves%20football">Stony Brook</a> became football-only members of the <a href="Colonial%20Athletic%20Association">Colonial Athletic Association</a> (CAA). Previously, they had respectively been football-only members of the <a href="Northeast%20Conference">Northeast Conference</a> and <a href="Big%20South%20Conference">Big South Conference</a>.
<a href="Georgia%20State%20Panthers%20football">Georgia State</a> left the FCS ranks to become a member of the <a href="Sun%20Belt%20Conference">Sun Belt Conference</a>. As it began its FBS transition in 2012, it was counted as an FBS member for scheduling purposes in 2013.
<a href="Old%20Dominion%20Monarchs%20football">Old Dominion</a> joined <a href="Conference%20USA">Conference USA</a> (C-USA) and started its FBS transition. ODU was technically an FCS independent in 2013 before becoming a provisional FBS member in 2014 and a full FBS member in 2015.
The <a href="Southland%20Conference">Southland Conference</a> added four schools—two with established football programs, one launching a new program, and another (<a href="New%20Orleans%20Privateers">New Orleans</a>) without varsity football. The established programs were <a href="2013%20Abilene%20Christian%20Wildcats%20football%20team">Abilene Christian</a> and <a href="2013%20Incarnate%20Word%20Cardinals%20football%20team">Incarnate Word</a>, both joining from the <a href="NCAA%20Division%20II">Division II</a> <a href="Lone%20Star%20Conference">Lone Star Conference</a>. While technically considered FCS independents in 2013, they played Division II schedules this season. Both would be counted as FCS members for scheduling purposes in 2014, at which time they began playing full Southland Conference schedules. <a href="2013%20Houston%20Baptist%20Huskies%20football%20team">Houston Baptist</a>, arriving from the Division I <a href="Great%20West%20Conference">Great West Conference</a>, fielded a football team for the first time in 2013, but only played a partial schedule. Houston Baptist also began playing a full Southland schedule in 2014.
<a href="Monmouth%20Hawks">Monmouth</a> announced in December 2012 that it would leave the <a href="Northeast%20Conference">Northeast Conference</a> (NEC) for the <a href="Metro%20Atlantic%20Athletic%20Conference">Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference</a> (MAAC), effective in July 2013. As the MAAC has not sponsored football since 2007, Monmouth's <a href="Monmouth%20Hawks%20football">football</a> plans were uncertain. Those plans became clear on February 14, 2013, when the <a href="Big%20South%20Conference">Big South Conference</a> announced that Monmouth would become a football-only member of that league in 2014. Since Monmouth was transitioning from the limited-scholarship NEC to a conference that allows the full FCS limit of 63 scholarship equivalents, the Hawks played the 2013 football season as an independent.
In addition to the schools changing conferences, three others launched FCS football programs. <a href="Charlotte%2049ers%20football">Charlotte</a>, which rejoined C-USA after eight years in the <a href="Atlantic%2010%20Conference">Atlantic 10 Conference</a>, played as an FCS independent in its first football season, as part of its announced plan to become a full FBS member in 2015. The 49ers were counted as an FBS program for scheduling purposes in 2014 and became a C-USA football member in 2015. Two other schools, <a href="Mercer%20Bears%20football">Mercer</a> and <a href="Stetson%20Hatters%20football">Stetson</a>, reinstated varsity football after decades-long absences—Mercer had last played in 1941 and Stetson in 1956. Both initially planned to operate as non-scholarship programs in the <a href="Pioneer%20Football%20League">Pioneer Football League</a>. However, Mercer would later commit to scholarship football when it accepted an invitation to join the <a href="Southern%20Conference">Southern Conference</a> (SoCon) in 2014.
Two other SoCon members, <a href="Appalachian%20State%20Mountaineers%20football">Appalachian State</a> and <a href="Georgia%20Southern%20Eagles%20football">Georgia Southern</a>, were officially announced on March 27, 2013 as future Sun Belt members. Both schools began FBS transitions in 2013 in advance of their 2014 entry into the Sun Belt. They were counted as FBS members for scheduling purposes in 2014, and were eligible for the Sun Belt football championship, but were not eligible for bowl games until completing their transitions in 2015.
This was also the last season for two other programs in their then-current conferences. <a href="Elon%20Phoenix%20football">Elon</a> left the SoCon for the CAA in July 2014; at the same time, <a href="VMI%20Keydets%20football">VMI</a> left the Big South and returned to the SoCon after an 11-year absence.

Coaching changes.
Preseason and in-season.
This is restricted to coaching changes that took place on or after May 1, 2013. For coaching changes that occurred earlier in 2013, see <a href="2012%20NCAA%20Division%20I%20FCS%20football%20season%23End%20of%20season">2012 NCAA Division I FCS end-of-season coaching changes</a>.
